newsitem.title: USA: Court issues $30 mln verdict in Honda case - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Court issues $30 mln verdict in Honda case - WSJ.

text.p: A district court has issued a $30 million verdict in the case of a 10-year-old driver killed after his Honda all-terrain vehicle flipped over, the Wall Street Journal said in its Friday electronic edition.

The boy's parents filed the wrongful death/product liability suit after the February 19, 1995, accident, alleging that the "Big Red" three-wheel vehicle their son was driving was defective, the paper said.
The report said a district court in Brownsville, Texas, found the auto-maker one-third liable and the boy's parents each one-third liable.

A Honda spokesman told the paper the company disagrees with the decision, because Texas legislation dictates that a plaintiff may only recover damages for negligence if his own responsibility does not exceed 60 percent.
The spokesman told the paper Honda believes there will be no payment under Texas law since the parents together were found 66-2/3 percent responsible.
The judge has not entered a judgement on the jury's verdict, and Honda declined to comment on its plans should the judge rule in the parents' favor, the report said.
